topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1: Host Linux Architecture

body.p: HPE Helion OpenStack Host Linux (Debian-based) project standardizes and controls our operating system environment for OpenStack services by combining Linux elements from Debian.org, Kernel.org, and foreign sources, to support our CI/CD processes.
The Host Linux repository provides a base Linux image for use by HPE Helion OpenStack (Helion) teams to package and build undercloud and overcloud nodes.

section.title: Service Description and Purpose
section.p: Host Linux is an HP-controlled, HP-internal only, Open Source Software Repository derived from the Debian GNU/Linux distribution and is tailored to support HPE Helion OpenStack product versions and OpenStack

Host Linux is instantiated as a binary and source code repository, which is available to HPE Helion OpenStack and constituent HPE development partners to create Host Linux operating system images as required for their specific and numerous product requirements.
Host Linux is the host operating system for HPE Helion OpenStack Community edition and HPE Helion OpenStack

Host Linux runs on physical servers (baremetal) to support the Helion stack, and is used to build images executing virtual OpenStack and Helion services, Host Linux also supports TripleO (OpenStack-on-OpenStack install, start-up, and operations.
Host Linux is internal and HP-use-only at this time, delivered to customers as a component of HPE Helion OpenStack and HPE Helion OpenStack Community.

section.title: Host Linux Repository
section.p: This section describes how Host Linux repository integrates Debian.org, Kernel.org, and foreign sources. The repository allows partners to select any current or archived packages, as needed.
The packages in the repository are refreshed with each HPE Helion OpenStack release.
Benefits of using the Host Linux repository instead of the Debian.org, Kernel.org, and foreign sources include:

ul.li: The packages are optimized to work with HPE Helion OpenStack
The repository is more secure and provides a smaller attack surface

section.title: Debian.org
section.p: The HPE Helion OpenStack Host Linux repository contains a focused set of 576 Debian packages, Host Linux re-branded. The Debian.org repository contains approximately 65,000 packages.

section.title: Kernel.org
section.p: The HPE Helion OpenStack Host Linux repository contains the full set of 6 Kernel.org packages, optimized to work with HPE Helion OpenStack including kernel parameter tuning, removal of modules not required by Helion, and added drivers.

section.title: Foreign Packages
section.p: The HPE Helion OpenStack Host Linux repository contains 8 non-Debian packages and 10 Debian packages.
These packages provide required HPE Helion OpenStack support not provided in OpenStack

section.title: Components
section.p: debian.org

ul.li: An operating system composed of free software mostly carrying the GNU General Public License.The operating system is developed by an internet collaboration of volunteers.

section.p: kernel.org

ul.li: A main repository of source code for the Linux kernel

section.p: WWW

ul.li: FLOSS not found in Debian, but available on the Web.

section.p: seedy.fc.hp.com

ul.li: Mirrors Debian, providing a local Debian mirror for use within the HPE Intranet.

section.p: hlinux-incoming.usa.hp.com

ul.li:
Used to download and assemble packages:
Mirror Debian "testing", a subset of the Debian Distribution. (also a few other Debian packages as needed)
Download and create custom builds of Linux Kernel
Download and package other software outside of Debian on request

section.p: hlinux-deejay.usa.hp.com

ul.li:
Generate index files
Repo signing
Generate package checksums

section.p: hlinux-hrepo.usa.hp.com

ul.li: Used by developers to access the Host Linux repo
Fetches packages from deejay as needed

li.p: seedy.fc.hp.com connects to an official Debian mirror site.

a. Access Control: none (hp proxy is needed to access internet) b. Protocol: HTTP/FTP c. Authenticity is ensured via the Debian public key used to validate the repository manifest, and by checksums on the Debian packages held therein. d. Timing: Changes pulled 4x each day.

a. Access Control: none b. Protocol: HTTP/FTP c. Authenticity is ensured via the Debian public key used to validate the repository manifest, and by checksums on the Debian packages held therein. d. Timing: Changes are pulled 1x each week, or needed for bug/security updates

a. Access Control: none (hp proxy is needed to access internet) b. Protocol: HTTPS c. Authenticity is ensured via 3rd party certificate authority (HTTPS) and by checksums on the Kernel downloads. d. Timing: Changes are pulled as needed, generally following Debian release schedule ~2x per month, or as needed for bug/security updates
hlinux-incoming.usa.hp.com connects to various software download locations on the internet.

a. Access Control: none? (hp proxy is needed to access internet) b. Protocol: HTTP/HTTPS/FTP c. Authenticity is ensured via 3rd party certificate authority (HTTPS) and by checksums on downloads WHEN AVAILABLE. d. Timing: Change pulls are driven by cloud team requesting the software.
(a) hLinux-deejay.usa.hp.com connects to hlinux-incoming.usa.hp.com; (b) hlinux-incoming.usa.hp.com connects to hLinux-deejay.usa.hp.com.

a. Access Control: username/password -or- secure key b. Protocol: SSH, SFTP c. Authenticity is ensured via the Debian public key used to validate the repository manifest, and by checksums on the Debian packages held therein. d. Timing: Packages are pushed when they have changed, in response to downloads and kernel builds.

a. Access Control: none b. Protocol: HTTP c. Authenticity is ensured via the HPE public key used to validate the repository manifest, and by checksums on the hLinux packages held therein. d. Timing: Packages are pulled in response to requests initiated by HPE Cloud Engineers
HPE Cloud Engineers connect to hlinux-hrepo.usa.hp.com

a. Access Control: none b. Protocol: HTTP c. Authenticity is ensured via the HPE public key used to validate the repository manifest, and by checksums on the hLinux packages held therein. d. Timing: Packages are requested as needed.
